Award.AwardTitle: Controlling the Behavior of Ferroelectric Materials through Strain Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Society and industry are increasingly calling upon novel materials to enable new capabilities and new applications. One example of a class of materials that is growing in terms of its use and technological impact are ferroelectric materials. These materials can produce a voltage or electric current when subjected to force (i.e., when compressed or bent) or vice-versa, they can produce movement when a voltage is applied to them. Ferroelectric materials are already utilized in a wide array of applications ranging from positioning systems (e.g., movement of the tips on atomic force microscopes) to energy harvesting (e.g., producing electric current from shoes during walking). This project will explore new ways to control the behavior and properties of ferroelectric materials by developing new materials, referred to here as flexoelectric materials, that are ferroelectric and that are made using modern material deposition methods which produce materials that have varying amounts of atomic level strain (i.e., deformation) built into them. In other words, by depositing the materials in a very controlled way, the normal distances between atoms in the material can be changed in a desired way and this displacement of atoms from their normal equilibrium will result in changes in the material properties. The project will train the next generation of scientists and engineers who can function in a multi-disciplinary team environment and will broadly enhance the infrastructure in the United States as it pertains to the synthesis and fabrication of complex materials. The project will also utilize education and outreach programs that are designed to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in science and engineering.

The goal of the project is to develop new insights into how inhomogeneous strains (such as strain gradients) can be produced and used to control flexoelectric materials. In particular, scientific framework will be developed to utilize modern thin-film deposition and processing routes to expand the fundamental understanding and utilization of flexoelectric effects (the coupling between a strain gradient and electric polarization). The project will explore the nature and limits of flexoelectricity in ferroelectrics by combining design, synthesis, processing, and characterization of materials. In situ and ex situ processing methodologies will be developed to produce large and tunable inhomogeneous strains (i.e., strain gradients) via the fabrication of flexible and free-standing ferroelectric films. The program will answer two central questions: 1) how can large and deterministic strain gradients be produced, and 2) how does the presence of a large strain gradient impact the field, stress, and temperature susceptibilities of a ferroelectric material? In situ synthesis of large strain gradients in films via the production of compositional and defect gradients will be explored. Ex situ fabrication and processing methods to produce large strain gradients in substrate-supported materials will be explored, together with released and free-standing versions of materials, and the evolution of properties in materials with large strain gradients. This work will impact the fields of ferroic materials, including ferroelectric-based properties, and will have has direct impact on devices that utilize ferroelectrics including memory and logic, sensors and actuators, thermal and energy conversion applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a scientific framework to utilize modern thin-film and processing routes to expand our fundamental understanding and utilization of materials under strain. Applying strain to materials can lead to new and useful behaviors and phases. For this project, experimental studies were performed on two types of materials: graphene, a two-dimensional lattice of carbon atoms that changes electronic properties when strained, and ferroelectrics, which can switch electrical polarization with applied field or strain. The research goals were accomplished on multiple fronts:

 

Intellectual merit:

The major outcomes of this research were significant advances in (1) determining the interplay between composition, defect-properties, and strain in driving the properties of ferroelectric thin films and (2) developing and demonstrating substrate-engineering to produce large strain gradients in membranes.

For the ferroelectric films, both experiments and modeling were used to show that PbZr1−xTixO3 film orientation, epitaxial strain, and composition combine in unexpected ways to drive exotic phase stability and transformations which are important to devices utilizing these materials. Further results showed that controlled composition and strain gradients enabled deterministic control of domains in PbZr1-xTixO3 heterostructures, providing new modalities of domain engineering and potential for as-yet-unrealized nanoscale functional devices. In addition, using piezoresponse force microscopy, it was shown that the basis of large field-driven responses in functional materials—i.e., competition between domain structures—could be induced via strain on PbTiO3 films. Results on the ferroelectrics PbTiO3 and BiFeO3 showed that defect engineering could dramatically improve device properties, such as strongly reduced leakage currents. In Ba1-xSrxTiO3 films it was demonstrated that composition and strain gradients result in very large spatial polarization gradients, which allows for large dielectric permittivity with low loss, negligible temperature-dependence, and high-dielectric tunability, making the films more suitable for use in on-chip devices.

The other sets of major advances from this research related to developing ex-situ fabrication and processing methods to produce large strain gradients in membranes. In particular, nano-patterning of substrates was used to induce strain in graphene, creating for the first time electronic device-compatible strain-tuning of a 2D membrane, which could then be used for novel nanoelectronics applications. Techniques were developed to fabricate substrates patterned with arrays of nanoscale triangular pyramids; when graphene was placed on top of these pyramids, large areas of non-uniform strain could be induced and controlled by changing the array aspect ratio and/or topological arrangement. In addition, a technique was developed to control strain in graphene by fabricating graphene devices on nanoparticle substrates. It was shown that the adhesion to the nanoparticles induces strain in the graphene, and the amount of strain depends on the nanoparticle diameter. Further, the research demonstrated that an underlying array of nanoparticles creates an “artificial lattice” in graphene, where the graphene experiences periodic height modulation and new electronic behavior—such as band gaps and large effective magnetic fields—from the “strain lattice”. The designed 2D crystal-nanoparticle heterostructure enables a new route to modulate the spatial pattern of strain in membranes and thereby tailor the electronic properties of the system.

 

Broader Impact:

The improved understanding of and technical capabilities in creating strained 2D membranes and ferroelectrics should have significant impact on both fundamental science and applications. The research results clarified long-standing open questions about the interplay between electronic properties and strain in key materials, and enabled new routes toward applications. The research supported by this program is timely and important for the development of a number of applications including memory, logic, sensing, energy conversion (transduction), etc. that utilize 2D membranes and ferroelectrics. Results from this research were broadly disseminated: 27 peer-reviewed papers, mostly in top journals, were published based on work from this grant. In addition, the PIs gave many research talks on this topic,  participated in workshops, published review papers, and incorporated the research into an undergraduate course. The students involved in this project were all trained in advanced fabrication and measurement techniques, relevant to training a workforce for future technologies. The research contributed to broadening participation in science and increasing the scientific workforce by training not just graduate students, but also multiple undergraduates, high school students, and a high school teacher. Further, the researchers included a significant fraction of people under-represented in physics and materials research. The PIs also engaged in significant outreach activities, such as recruiting programs, and talks to teachers, students, and to communities traditionally under-represented in physics.
